question: With an Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System:

choices.choice: the secondary display will show continuously the engine primary instruments.
the primary display unit will continuously show the engine primary instruments such as N1 N2 N3 and maybe oil pressure.
the primary engine display will continuously show the engine primary instruments such as N1 EGT and maybe EPR.
the primary engine instruments are N1 EGT and EPR and are on the primary and secondary display units.

subject: Instruments

question: The electronic engine display system with three automatic modes is:

choices.choice: the Electronic Centralised Aircraft Monitor, with the fourth mode manual.
the Electronic Centralised Aircraft Monitor, with the fourth mode flight phase related or manual.
the Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System, with the fourth mode manual
the Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System, with the fourth mode a manual cross over from the Electronic Centralised Aircraft Monitor System

explanation:
Display Modes

There are four display modes:

  1. Flight Phase-Related Mode – Automatically selected based on the current flight phase.
  2. Advisory Mode (Mode and Status) – Provides status updates and advisories.
  3. Failure-Related Mode – Displays failure indications and alerts.
  4. Manual Mode – Controlled manually by the pilot.

Additionally, the Aircraft System Display provides detailed system information as needed
subject: Instruments

question: The display modes for the Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System are:

choices.choice: operational, status and maintenance of which status and maintenance are automatic.
flight phase related, advisory and failure related.
operational, status and maintenance
operational, flight phase related and status.

explanation:
Display Modes

EICAS categorizes displays and alerts based on function and usage. There are three modes of displaying information:

  1. Operational Mode – Provides real-time engine and system parameters for flight operations.
  2. Status Mode – Displays aircraft system status and advisories.
  3. Maintenance Mode – Used for troubleshooting and detailed system diagnostics.
subject: Instruments

question: With an Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System lower display unit failure

choices.choice: a compact message will only appear on the upper display unit.
a compact message will only appear on the central display unit.
a compact message will appear both on the upper display unit and the captains Electronic Flight Instrument System
a compact message will appear on the upper display unit when the status button is pressed on the control panel

explanation:
Display Unit Failure

  • If the lower display unit fails while showing secondary information, an amber alert message appears at the top left of the upper display unit.
  • The secondary information is automatically transferred to the upper display unit in a compact format (see Figure below).
  • The compact display can be removed by pressing the ENGINE switch on the display select panel.
  • A display unit failure inhibits the function of the STATUS switch, preventing the status page format from being displayed.
subject: Instruments

question: With an Electronic Centralised Aircraft Monitoring type of system:

choices.choice: the display units have two control panels and with any system failure the control will be from the port control box only.
the left display unit shows warning and corrective action in a check list format
the two display units are only fitted side by side.
the left display unit shows the synoptic format and the right or lower unit shows the corrective format.

subject: Instruments

question: The Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System alert messages are shown on the upper display unit in three forms:

choices.choice: Level ‘C' are warnings that require immediate corrective action.
Level ‘ A' are cautions that require immediate crew awareness and possible action
Level ‘B' are advisories requiring crew awareness.
and these messages appear on the top left of the upper display unit.

explanation:
Alert Messages

The system continuously monitors over 400 inputs from engine and airframe system sensors to detect malfunctions. When an issue is identified, appropriate messages are displayed on the upper display unit, prioritized by urgency.

Up to 11 messages can be displayed at the following levels:

  • Level A – Warning (Red)
    • Requires immediate corrective action.
    • Displayed in red.
    • Master warning lights illuminate.
    • Aural warnings (e.g., fire bell) activate.
  • Level B – Caution (Amber)
    • Requires immediate crew awareness and future action.
    • Displayed in amber.
    • Accompanied by caution lights and an aural tone (repeated twice).
  • Level C – Advisory (Amber)
    • Requires crew awareness only.
    • Displayed in amber.
    • No caution lights or aural tones.
subject: Instruments

question: The electronic engine display system will have:

choices.choice: one primary and one secondary display unit for an EICAS and a change over selector to change to the ECAM mode if necessary.
two display units for ECAM and three display units for EICAS.
either EICAS or ECAM but not both.
an interconnect to the EFIS symbol generators in an emergency.

explanation:
The display units form part of two principal systems designated as Engine Indicating and Crew
Alerting System (EICAS), and Electronic Centralized Aircraft Monitoring (ECAM) system.

 

EICAS – Boeing

ECAM -Airbus
subject: Instruments

question: In an Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System if both displays fail then the following information is displayed on the standby engine indicator:

choices.choice: N1, EGT, N2.
N1, EGT, EPR.
N2, EGT, EPR.
N4, EGT, EPR.

explanation:
Standby Engine Indicator

The Standby Engine Indicator provides primary engine information in case of a total EICAS display failure.

  • Displays N1 and N2 speeds, EGT, and operating limit values (see Figure ).
  • Uses an LCD-type display for clear visibility.

This ensures that critical engine parameters remain available even in the event of a full EICAS failure.
subject: Instruments

question: The Electronic Centralised Aircraft Monitor (ECAM) type of system shows a:

choices.choice: checklist format on the left display panel and schematic form always automatically on the right display unit.
checklist format on the left display unit and the right, or lower display unit , a diagram or synoptic format.
synoptic format on the left display unit and a warning and corrective action display on the right or lower display unit.
continuous primary engine display on the primary display unit.

subject: Instruments

question: The electronic display system that has three automatic modes plus one manual is the:

choices.choice: Electronic Management and Control Section.
Electronic Indication and Fail Safe system.
Electronic Indication and Crew Alert system.
Electronic Centralised Aircraft Monitor.

explanation:
Display Modes

There are four display modes:

  1. Flight Phase-Related Mode – Automatically selected based on the current flight phase.
  2. Advisory Mode (Mode and Status) – Provides status updates and advisories.
  3. Failure-Related Mode – Displays failure indications and alerts.
  4. Manual Mode – Controlled manually by the pilot.

Additionally, the Aircraft System Display provides detailed system information as needed
subject: Instruments

question: A boxed message shown as an electronic engine display system fault is one that:

choices.choice: affects other sub-systems and is used in the Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System.
does not affect any other system.
does not affect any other system and is used in the Engine Indicating and Aircraft Monitor system.
affects other sub-systems and is used in the Electronic Centralised Aircraft Monitor type of system.

explanation: In cases where a failure can affect other sub-systems, the title of the sub-system is shown ‘boxed’, as for instance in the display shown in Figure
subject: Instruments

question: An engine fire indication on an electronic engine display is shown:

choices.choice: on the primary display panel in red.
on the secondary display panel in amber.
on both the Electronic Flight Instrument System and Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System secondary panels.
only on the Flight Management Computer primary panel.

explanation: • Level A – Warning (Red)  Warning requiring immediate corrective action. They are displayed in red. Masterwarning lights are also illuminated, and aural warnings (e.g. fire bell) from a central warning system are given.
subject: Instruments

question: An engine electronic system which in normal conditions of flight shows only the primary engine instruments is:

choices.choice: An EICAS system with EPR, EGT and N2 shown on the primary instruments.
An ECAM system with the primary engine instruments displayed on the lower screen.
An EICAS system with the primary engine instruments displayed on the primary screen, the secondary screen being blank.
An ECAM system with the primary engine instruments displayed on the primary screen, the left screen being blank.

explanation:
Display Modes

EICAS categorizes displays and alerts based on function and usage. There are three modes of displaying information:

  1. Operational Mode –The operational mode displays the engine operating information and any alerts required to be actioned by the crew in flight. Normally only the upper display unit presents information, the lower one remains blank and can be selected to display secondary information as and when required.
  2. Status Mode – Displays aircraft system status and advisories.
  3. Maintenance Mode – Used for troubleshooting and detailed system diagnostics.
subject: Instruments
